text: hello everyone today I'll be showcasing
a feature of AWS Secrets manager the
secret count metric in Amazon Cloud
watch
for those who are not familiar with the
service AWS Secrets manager is a service
that helps you manage retrieve and
rotate database credentials API keys and
other Secrets throughout their life
cycles
let's take a minute to talk about the
secrets count metric from Secrets
manager
Secrets manager publishes a metric to
Amazon cloudwatch for the number of
secrets in your account
with this feature you can easily review
how many secrets you are using in
Secrets manager you can also set alarms
for an unexpected increase or decrease
in the number of secrets in your account
now that we've talked about the feature
let's jump into the AWS console in this
demo I'll show you where you can find
this metric in the cloud watch console
and walk you through the creation of an
alarm that will notify Us by email if
the number of secrets in our account
goes beyond a certain threshold
once I'm in the console I'll select the
AWS Secrets manager service
you can see I currently have a couple of
Secrets stored in this account in this
region
next we'll head over to the cloud watch
console
now we will need to locate the secret
count metric
let's view the metrics available by
clicking on the metrics tab on the left
side of the page
we can then locate the metric by
selecting all metrics and searching for
Secrets manager in the search bar
we will then select AWS Secrets manager
and click the checkbox to add the secret
count metric to our graph
once you've graphed the metric you
should see the same number of secrets in
cloudwatch as you did in the secrets
manager console
now we can create an alarm to notify us
when a given Secret's threshold has been
exceeded
first we will select all alarms
and then click the button to create a
new alarm
we will first be asked to select a
metric for our alarm
you may be shown the secret count metric
by default or alternatively you could
search for it in the search bar as we
did before
now you can check the box next to the
metric and click select metric to
continue
we will leave the metric values as
default and focus on the conditions
during which our alarm will go off
when creating the alarm we have the
ability to either Define a static
threshold or use cloudwatch anomaly
detection to determine when the alarm
should go into effect
for this demonstration we will use a
static threshold let's define the
threshold as greater than 2.
if we scroll back up to the graph we
will be able to see the alarm threshold
in red and what the current resource
count is in blue
let's click next to configure the
actions for the alarm
here I'll configure the alarm to send a
notification to an SNS topic when it is
in an alarm state
I'll select create a new SNS topic and
name it Secrets manager resource count
alarm
this way I will get an email when too
many Secrets have been created in my
account
I'll enter an email and click create
topic the rest of the settings can be
left as default
I'll click next to continue
I'll give my alarm a name and select
next to review the configurations that
I've put
once I'm satisfied with all of my
configurations I'll scroll down to the
bottom and create the alarm
and that's it we've created a new alarm
in cloudwatch that will notify us if the
amount of secrets in our account rises
above a specific threshold
thanks for your time and make sure to
consult the AWS Secrets manager
documentation for more information on
monitoring secrets with AWS Secrets
manager in Amazon cloudwatch
